lead_paragraph: UBS said its wealth management chief, Raoul Weil, has left the bank to focus on his legal defense after a grand jury indicted him on a charge of conspiring to help wealthy Americans hide assets from the Internal Revenue Service. Mr. Weil, 49, faces up to five years in prison if convicted. Federal prosecutors said in a Nov. 6 indictment that he and other executives failed to put effective restrictions in place to stop UBS’s American clients from evading taxes. Mr. Weil’s lawyer, Aaron Marcu, said his client did not violate any laws.

lead_paragraph: Shares of the Simon Property Group, the biggest American shopping mall owner, fell 8 percent after the company cut its dividend and 2009 earnings forecast. The dividend will be 60 cents a share in the next three quarters, down from 90 cents, Simon Property said in a statement. Simon Property lost almost half its stock market value in the past year as the recession reduced consumer spending and spurred job losses. “We’re optimistic that we’ll reinstate the full cash dividend” as the capital markets improve, the chief executive, David Simon, said.

lead_paragraph: Banks in Georgia and New Jersey were seized by regulators, raising the tally of failed lenders in the United States to 31. Silverton Bank of Atlanta, a commercial bank, was shut by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and Citizens Community Bank in Ridgewood, N.J., was seized by the state’s Department of Banking and Insurance. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was named receiver in both cases. Silverton Bank had about $4.1 billion in assets and $3.3 billion in deposits, and Citizens Community Bank had assets of $45.1 million and deposits of $43.7 million.

In five years, he changed jobs three times, quadrupling his salary along the way. Even when satisfied with his position, he kept his résumé posted on job sites, in case better offers came along. And he splurged. In three years, he bought three cars, moving up a notch in luxury each time. For weekend jaunts, he bought a motorcycle.

abstract: Remembering a journalist who practiced an important but dwindling role — the investigative reporter.
snippet: Remembering a journalist who practiced an important but dwindling role — the investigative reporter.
lead_paragraph: My friend John Wilke died late last week. He was only 54, and had spent the great bulk of his career at The Wall Street Journal as an investigative reporter. As I was talking to mutual friends over the weekend, mourning, we all kept noting how his passing wasn’t just a personal loss, as huge as that was. His death meant that an important but dwindling role in American journalism — the investigative reporter — had lost one of one its finest practitioners.

headline.main: In Praise of John Wilke

abstract: An interview with Doug Tatum, a financial consultant and champion of a tax-deferral plan that he says could unleash the job-creating power of small businesses.
snippet: An interview with Doug Tatum, a financial consultant and champion of a tax-deferral plan that he says could unleash the job-creating power of small businesses.
lead_paragraph: Despite billions of dollars of bailout and stimulus money, the credit squeeze that kicked off our current economic crisis shows few signs of abating. Generally speaking, banks still aren’t lending, and small businesses are still struggling to find ways to finance their operations. To get a better feel for how business owners are coping, Darren Dahl recently spoke with Doug Tatum, co-founder and chairman emeritus of Tatum, an Atlanta-based consulting and executive search firm that specializes in helping growing companies with finance issues. In recent years, Mr. Tatum, the author of “No Man’s Land: What to Do When Your Company Is Too Big to Be Small and Too Small to Be Big” (Portfolio, 2007), has spent considerable time on Capitol Hill pitching a tax-deferral plan of his design that has had the support of two United States senators, John Kerry and Olympia J. Snowe, who have long been active in small-business issues.

headline.main: Why Small Businesses Still Can’t Borrow Money

All this is to explain that I love this puzzle, but I realize I can’t tease apart an objective analysis from my emotional connections. Not only that, I don’t want to! abstract: The McDonald’s Corporation said global sales rose 6.9 percent in April, as consumers bought more coffee drinks and chicken snack wraps.
snippet: The McDonald’s Corporation said global sales rose 6.9 percent in April, as consumers bought more coffee drinks and chicken snack wraps.
lead_paragraph: The McDonald’s Corporation, the world’s largest restaurant company, said global sales rose 6.9 percent in April, topping analysts’ estimates, as consumers bought more coffee drinks and chicken snack wraps. Sales at domestic restaurants open at least 13 months climbed 6.1 percent, while European orders increased 8.4 percent, McDonald’s said. Sales in Asia, the Middle East and Africa gained 6.5 percent. Big Macs, Quarter Pounders and French fries lifted American sales, in addition to demand for chicken wraps and McCafe espresso-based drinks, the company said.

headline.main: 6.9%. Sales Increase at McDonald’s Beats Estimates

abstract: The chief executive of Vranken-Pommery Monopole said the French company was skirting an industry contraction by selling cheaper bubbly than larger competitors.
snippet: The chief executive of Vranken-Pommery Monopole said the French company was skirting an industry contraction by selling cheaper bubbly than larger competitors.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Vranken-Pommery Monopole, the world’s third-biggest maker of Champagne, said the French company was skirting an industry contraction by selling cheaper bubbly than larger competitors. Champagne revenue at Vranken fell 2.4 percent in the first quarter, less than the 29 percent slump at the No. 2 maker, Boizel Chanoine Champagne. LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the biggest Champagne producer, said the number of bottles sold in the period fell 35 percent, but it does not break out Champagne sales. Vranken’s Charles Lafitte, popular in France, costs about 20 euros ($27) a bottle.

headline.main: Champagne Drinkers Lean Toward the Cheap Stuff
headline.print_headline: Champagne Drinkers Lean Toward the Cheap Stuff

lead_paragraph: The White House has added $1.15 billion to a fund meant to settle claims made under a discrimination lawsuit filed by black farmers against the Department of Agriculture. The money, along with $100 million allocated in last year’s farm bill, is meant to compensate farmers filing claims after settlement in 1999 of a suit accusing the government of denying agricultural loans to black farmers. Restitution was delayed for years as officials decided how claims should be heard and payments distributed.

headline.main: Obama Adds Money to Pay Black Farmers for Bias

lead_paragraph: Richemont, the Swiss maker of Cartier watches and Montblanc pens, eked out a modest rise in sales last year. But the company’s chairman, Johann Rupert said the near-term outlook for luxury goods remained grim. “People are spending less on discretionary goods,” he said. “We shouldn’t be surprised by this.” Richemont said net profit for the year through March fell 31 percent from a year earlier, to 1.1 billion euros (about $1.5 billion), hurt by restructuring costs. Revenue rose 2 percent, to 5.4 billion euros, but that figure was entirely the result of a 10 percent first-half rise, as sales fell 5 percent in the second half amid a deepening economic crisis.

headline.main: Small Profit for Luxury Goods Company

The basis of his best-selling book “The Long Tail” was a statistical phenomenon called the Pareto distribution; in his coming book, “Free,” he expresses arguments in profit-loss charts. The walls in his San Francisco office are whiteboards, covered with scrawled formulas.

lead_paragraph: Each May, TV networks host “upfronts,” shorthand for an annual rite of passage for television networks and the industry that operates in orbit around them. It generally refers to three activities:No. 1: The unveiling of new television network schedulesNo. 2: The cajoling of advertisers by the networksNo. 3: The selling of billions of dollars in advertising timeNo. 1 is the most important for fans who want to know if their favorite shows will return and which new shows will join the schedule. Nos. 2 and 3 are the most important to networks who want to keep shows in production and keep generating profit for their parent companies, an especially tough task this year.

abstract: Two networks owned by the Walt Disney Company — ABC and ESPN — expressed hopeful outlooks at separate upfront presentations on Tuesday morning.

lead_paragraph: TIP OF THE WEEK Google’s new Search Options feature unveiled last week (snipurl.com/i1u5s) includes a couple of inventive ways to see your results. After you click the “Show options” link on the search results page, a link in the left column lets you see your hits as a Wonder Wheel  a graphic that shows the search term encircled by a set of links leading to related key words and phrases. Image and standard Web page results are also listed on the right side of the page. The left column on the Options page has a Timeline view as well, which tries to sort results based on chronological order.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Google’s New Search Options

abstract: Comparing the commencement speeches the Fed chairman gave last year and this year.
snippet: Comparing the commencement speeches the Fed chairman gave last year and this year.
lead_paragraph: Today Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave a commencement speech at the Boston College School of Law. It sounded remarkably more hopeful, and less crisis-oriented, than his speech last year at Harvard’s Class Day (which apparently flopped; video here). Which seemed odd to me, given that the setting for the venue last year was supposed to be more comical (Harvard’s Class Day is usually orated by a comedian like Will Ferrell), and that, to the casual observer, the economy seems to be in much more trouble in May this year than June last year.

headline.main: Green Shoots?: Bernanke ’08 vs. Bernanke ’09

abstract: A Saturday puzzle with large thumb spikes.
snippet: A Saturday puzzle with large thumb spikes.
lead_paragraph: Let’s see, what might “Words written on some test papers” be? Well, to start with, there are the questions. Those are mostly words. Too long. Then there are answers, some correct, others not so correct. Doesn’t fit. That’s it, right? Not quite. Eventually you get those test papers handed back, and if you’re very unlucky, you’ll see a certain two-word phrase scrawled along the top: SEE ME. What a wonderful clue, even if it gave me the shivers.

lead_paragraph: American makers of pipes used for oil wells are being harmed by a surge of Chinese imports, a federal agency ruled in a decision that may lead to tariffs of as much as 99 percent on $2.6 billion in goods. The International Trade Commission ruled in favor of companies including United States Steel, Wheatland Tube Company, and the American operations of Evraz Group. The ruling may be a precursor for a number of trade complaints against China as the contracting economy prompts American companies to seek protection.

abstract: Three California men were charged with running a $200 million Ponzi scheme involving thousands of investors, the state attorney general, Jerry Brown, said. The men used investors’ money to finance their estates, jets and cars before their Ponzi scheme collapsed, causing some retired investors to lose their life savings, Mr. Brown said. The defendants — James Stanley Koenig, Gary T. Armitage and Jeffrey A . Guidi — used real estate seminars to attract investments of more than $1 million, Mr. Brown said.

abstract: UBS, Deutsche Bank, JPMorgan Chase and Depfa Bank have dropped an appeal against the seizure of $482 million of their assets amid an investigation of fraud.
snippet: UBS, Deutsche Bank, JPMorgan Chase and Depfa Bank have dropped an appeal against the seizure of $482 million of their assets amid an investigation of fraud.
lead_paragraph: UBS, Deutsche Bank, JPMorgan Chase and Depfa Bank have dropped an appeal against the seizure of 345 million euros ($482 million) of their assets amid an investigation of fraud involving derivatives sold to the city of Milan, said two lawyers representing the banks. The banks dropped the appeal at a hearing in Milan on Monday. The prosecutor is considering a May 7 request by the securities firms to put up about 100 million euros ($140 million) in exchange for having the assets returned, the lawyers said. Milan is suing the four banks after it lost money on derivatives it bought from the lenders in 2005. The banks earned about 101 million euros ($141.5 million) in what prosecutors called illicit profit from arranging the contracts. Officials for Deutsche Bank and Depfa declined to comment. The claims will be discussed in the course of the investigation, said UBS's lawyer Giuseppe Bana. Given "the very short notice between the filing by the prosecutor of a large volume of documentation and the date set for the hearing it has not been possible adequately to address the relevant issues in time for the hearing. However, we are confident that the strength of our legal position will ultimately be demonstrated through the judicial process," a JPMorgan spokesman said in an e-mailed statement. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline.main: Four Big Banks Drop Appeal in Milan Case
headline.print_headline: Four Big Banks Drop Appeal in Milan Case

abstract: The chairman of India's Tata Motors, Ratan Tata, had 500 engineers work for four years designing the world's lowest-cost car, convinced that cost-conscious Indian drivers could live without air-conditioning and cup holders. But only 20 percent of Tata's initial 203,000 orders for the car — the Nano — were for the no-frills $2,600 model. Instead, customers booked models at the higher end some costing as much as 40 percent more, or about $3,680. The higher prices mean bigger margins for Tata and less chance of a profit-sapping price war with rival carmakers like Maruti Suzuki India, analysts said. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

abstract: Porsche is in danger of losing some of the 17.3 billion euros in profit recorded from holding VW options because it may not have the money to exercise them.
snippet: Porsche is in danger of losing some of the 17.3 billion euros in profit recorded from holding VW options because it may not have the money to exercise them.
lead_paragraph: Porsche, which is trying to combine with Volkswagen is in danger of losing some of the 17.3 billion euros ($24.3 billion) in profit recorded from holding VW options because it may not have the money to exercise them. Porsche bought options and Volkswagen stock for more than three years and controls more than 70 percent of VW. Now, Porsche may be unable to raise the money needed to cash in the options, according to research by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, Sal. Oppenheim Jr. and FAIResearch. Porsche has not been able to raise the financing even after the options contracts surged in value along with the sevenfold gain in VW shares since 2005, according to the analysts. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline.main: Porsche May Not Be Able to Profit From VW Options

abstract: Amgen is exercising an option to acquire the rights to an experimental drug to treat heart failure from Cytokinetics, a smaller biotechnology company.
snippet: Amgen is exercising an option to acquire the rights to an experimental drug to treat heart failure from Cytokinetics, a smaller biotechnology company.
lead_paragraph: Amgen is exercising an option to acquire the rights to an experimental drug to treat heart failure from Cytokinetics, a smaller biotechnology company. The deal would move Amgen, the world's biggest biotechnology company, into the field of cardiovascular medicine. Amgen paid $75 million to Cytokinetics more than two years ago for the option to the drug, which is called CK-1827452. Having now seen more data from clinical trials, Amgen has decided to assume control of further testing and commercialization of the drug and related compounds. Cytokinetics, which is based in South San Francisco, Calif., will receive $50 million from Amgen and is eligible for up to $600 million in future payments if the drug succeeds. The drug, now in the middle stage of clinical trials, works by activating cardiac myosin, a protein that helps heart muscles contract to pump blood. About 5 million Americans have chronic heart failure, in which the heart cannot pump blood adequately. ANDREW POLLACK

headline.main: Amgen Acquires Rights to New Heart Drug

abstract: The Queen’s English.
snippet: The Queen’s English.
lead_paragraph: Those wacky Brits. Just because the language is called “English,” they think it’s theirs. George Bernard Shaw (GBS in crossword grids) once said that “England and America are two countries separated by a common language.” Corey Rubin tries to bridge that divide today with theme phrases that draw from both sides. It’s a good theme because getting one answer helps with the others without giving them away. Plus the answers are funny.

headline.main: Favor One Side

abstract: It is becoming easier to break free of paper and pen and instead rely on computers to take notes that can be archived, cataloged and searched.

lead_paragraph: MODERN life is a mess of notes, a tangle of countless scraps of information that we accumulate during our waking hours. In the morning, you attend a meeting with the boss and jot down everything she says. Later, you get a call from the vet and transcribe results from your dog’s lab tests. At lunch, a friend gives you the name of a Mexican place he says you’ve got to try. And then there are the to-do lists, grocery lists, recipes and all those brilliant ideas for screenplays you get while taking a shower.

headline.main: Bringing Order to the Chaos of Notes

abstract: The appellate court opinions of Judge Sonia Sotomayor, now a Supreme Court nominee, do not put her clearly in a pro- or anti-business camp, lawyers say.
snippet: The appellate court opinions of Judge Sonia Sotomayor, now a Supreme Court nominee, do not put her clearly in a pro- or anti-business camp, lawyers say.
lead_paragraph: In the decade she has served on the Second Circuit Court of Appeals — the busiest appellate court for business and financial matters in the nation — Judge Sonia Sotomayor has authored some 150 civil and business cases and voted on hundreds more. But many lawyers and scholars who have examined her record closely say that her opinions in this field are unpredictable, and do not put her clearly in a pro- or anti-business camp, The New York Times’s John Schwartz writes.

headline.main: Sotomayor’s Opinions in Business Cases Cut Both Ways

abstract: What Bill Ackman did accomplish with his Target proxy fight.
snippet: What Bill Ackman did accomplish with his Target proxy fight.
lead_paragraph: I’m pretty rough on Bill Ackman, the hedge fund manager who mounting a proxy fight aimed at Target, in this week’s column. I feel a little badly about that because Bill is a smart guy whose work I have often admired (see my column about him taking on MBIA here). But the more I looked into it, the more I felt that Mr. Ackman was using the rhetoric of corporate governance to disguise his annoyance at having Target turn down his ideas. I’m sure he’ll give me an earful about this next week, but that’s a whole other story. I’ll blog about it if he does.

abstract: Arrange the odd letters.

lead_paragraph: This Sunday puzzle is a little different. The notepad reads, “Every letter in the answer to each asterisked clue appears an even number of times in that answer … except one. Altogether, these eight unpaired letters can be arranged to spell the answer to 68 and 70 Across.” Some themes help along the way, providing an extra dimension beyond the Down and Across clues. Today’s is more of a second puzzle to solve after you’ve nearly finished the first one. It can’t have been easy to find suitable theme answers that fit the even-odd letter requirement. I remember another Kelsey Blakley Sunday puzzle from 2007 that also put interesting constraints on the theme answers: (Across Lite, Solution).
